TopicTitle: Help extracting orbit data and plugging into Alexmoon's Launch Window Planner

Articles.Content:
I need to do some delta-V calculations starting from Moho and working inward toward Kerbol (where I have a stranded Kerbal).  I don't think the standard "subway map" Delta V charts will quite cut it for this, unless I'm interpreting them wrong, since the interplanetary stuff all goes through Kerbin's SOI edge.

I'm trying to add my target to Alexmoon's Launch Window Planner, but I'm not sure if I'm using the correct values.  Here's what comes from my savegame:

ORBIT
            {
                SMA = 2622873600
                ECC = 0.00166092964354903
                INC = -0.000212243452551775
                LPE = 0.999876499176025
                LAN = 0.999444901943207
                MNA = 2.97002827598779
                EPH = 0.999150812625885
                REF = 0
            }

Here's what comes from KER target info (read from a vessel that's parked on the KSC launchpad):

Here's what I've filled in so far, not sure if it's correct (e.g. inclination won't take negative values):

Help figuring out how to pull the correct values, convert to the correct units, etc, would be great!

Edited May 16, 2016 by Fwiffo

Nevermind, I found some additional metrics in KER that I could add to the target info window, I think it has everything I need.

Does this look correct?  I'm a bit surprised as this thing is telling me it's a lot cheaper (in terms of delta V) to leave from Kerbin than from orbit of Moho or Eve (I wanted to check from Gilly but that moon isn't in his planner):

Edited May 16, 2016 by Fwiffo

9 hours ago, Fwiffo said:

Does this look correct?  I'm a bit surprised as this thing is telling me it's a lot cheaper (in terms of delta V) to leave from Kerbin than from orbit of Moho or Eve (I wanted to check from Gilly but that moon isn't in his planner):

That doesn't look right to me.  7250m/s to transfer from Kerbin to a sub-Moho Pe, and only 1348m/s more (total dV - ejection dV) to match velocities with the target once you get there? That seems bass-ackwards to me at the very least.

As you probably know already, the transfer burn Kerbin to Moho is no big deal, in the 1500-2000m/s range.  The problem is matching velocities with Moho once you get there.  Unless you take special precautions, you'll likely find you need 6000-7000m/s to capture into Moho orbit.  This is why I think your numbers are backwards.

In any case, I would not use the AlexMoon thing at all for this mission, any more than I'd use it to get to Moho itself.  I would use the same method as most follks use to get to Moho.  This is because inherent inaccuracies in the game exceed the precision in execution needed (even by MJ) to get to Moho (or inside it) using a normal Hohmann or ballistic transfer.  There are many threads in this forum about how to get to Moho and I recommend you search for them for all the fine details.  But the general idea is pretty simple and can be summarized as follows:

1.  Totally ignore any and all transfer windows generated by anything like AlexMoon, MJ, KAC, or whatever.

2.  Leave Kerbin on whatever day its position in its orbit is lined up with the ascending/descending nodes of the target orbit.

3.  Do the transfer burn from Kerbin so that your future path will intersect the target orbit on the far side of the sun from where Kerbin is now, which will be at one of its ascending or descending nodes.

4.  Because you're having to rendezvous with a ship, you must adjust your inclination to match that of the target orbit.  Normally, you can skip this if going to Moho because you're intercepting it at or near a node.  But here, you need to do it and because you're at a node when you leave Kerbin, that's the place to do it.  So either put the necessary plane change in the actual transfer burn or wait until you're just outside of Kerbin's SOI to do it (not being quite on the node by then won't make much difference).

5.  Coast out to what is now your solar Pe.  Once you get there, retroburn to pull your solar Ap down from the vicinity of Kerbin's orbit to something between Moho and the target orbit.   You definitely don't want to get an accidental Moho encounter that will toss you out of position.

6.  Once this is done, see if you have any sort of close approach to the target.  If not, experiment by dragging a node around your orbit and giving it various tweaks.  The idea is to rendezvous in the vicinity of your solar Pe without having to burn a lot of fuel to achieve this.  If you can't do it the 1st time around the sun, check again next orbit.  You might have to wait several solar orbits before you synch up with your target.

2 hours ago, Geschosskopf said:

As you probably know already, the transfer burn Kerbin to Moho is no big deal, in the 1500-2000m/s range.  The problem is matching velocities with Moho once you get there.  Unless you take special precautions, you'll likely find you need 6000-7000m/s to capture into Moho orbit.  This is why I think your numbers are backwards.

 

Disregarding inclination, your velocity relative to Moho, coming from Kerbin, is between 2400 m/s (at Moho's Pe) and 3900 m/s (at Moho's Ap). If you need 6000 m/s to match orbits with Moho, something has gone very wrong.

 

12 hours ago, Fwiffo said:

Does this look correct?  I'm a bit surprised as this thing is telling me it's a lot cheaper (in terms of delta V) to leave from Kerbin than from orbit of Moho or Eve (I wanted to check from Gilly but that moon isn't in his planner):
 

This doesn't look right at all.

My spreadsheet (which works fine when I plug the stock planets' parameters in, except for inclination which I haven't added in yet) tells me that to get to this vessel's orbit, you need a Vinf of 4004* m/s leaving Kerbin (compared to a maximum Vinf of 2900 m/s to reach Moho's Pe), and you will need 6230 m/s to match orbits with it.

Leaving from Eve, you'd need a Vinf of 3830m/s and an orbit-matching burn of 5420m/s (on average, again discounting inclination changes).

And leaving from Moho, you'd need a Vinf of somewhere between 1740 m/s (if you leave at Moho's Ap) and 3660m/s (if you leave at Moho's Pe) and orbit-matching burn of between 4000 m/s in the first case and 2300 m/s in the second case.

The real numbers from Moho will be significantly higher since Moho's incination is a killer.

*(edit: checking another formula I had saved somewhere, a Vinf of 4004 on leaving Kerbin's SOI requires a burnout velocity of 5148m/s from an altitude of 75km around Kerbin. Deducting orbital velocity of slightly less than 2300 m/s leaves an ejection burn of about 2850m/s from LKO.) 

Edited May 16, 2016 by Plusck

4 minutes ago, Plusck said:

Disregarding inclination, your velocity relative to Moho, coming from Kerbin, is between 2400 m/s (at Moho's Pe) and 3900 m/s (at Moho's Ap). If you need 6000 m/s to match orbits with Moho, something has gone very wrong.

Sure, in theory.  In practice, due to the inherent inaccuracies introduced by the game interface, you are extremely unlikely to meet Moho so cleanly.  It's a lot better to do a bi-elliptic transfer than to go straight there.

Just now, Geschosskopf said:

Sure, in theory.  In practice, due to the inherent inaccuracies introduced by the game interface, you are extremely unlikely to meet Moho so cleanly.  It's a lot better to do a bi-elliptic transfer than to go straight there.

The only sensible way to get to Moho, as far as I'm concerned, is to leave at the Moho/Kerbin AN/DN, opposite Moho's Pe (well in fact, that's impossible since Moho's Pe is not at AN/DN, but as close as possible). The ejection burn should be angled about 16° in the opposite direction from the angle of Moho's orbit to minimise plane change later. At Pe, you then burn retrograde until you get a capture one orbit later.

In general, this means a 2500 m/s or so ejection burn, a 600-800m/s burn at Moho's Pe to get an encounter, then a 2000 m/s capture burn. The numbers may be off by a few hundred m/s (I can't remember exactly what I got last time I did this) but certainly not by thousands.

I don't think a bi-elliptic transfer would help, since if you head outwards from Kerbin you are massively increasing the velocity tocapture, and if you head inwards you're losing the benefit of the Oberth effect by not doing the whole burn at Kerbin. And if you go even further down than Moho, you're magnifying the plane-change cost.

1 minute ago, Plusck said:

The only sensible way to get to Moho, as far as I'm concerned, is to leave at the Moho/Kerbin AN/DN, opposite Moho's Pe (well in fact, that's impossible since Moho's Pe is not at AN/DN, but as close as possible). The ejection burn should be angled about 16° in the opposite direction from the angle of Moho's orbit to minimise plane change later. At Pe, you then burn retrograde until you get a capture one orbit later.

But because you're leaving when Kerbin is in the right place vs. Moho's orbit, you're paying no attention to where on its orbit Moho is at the time.  Thus, it's not likely that Moho will be at its node when your ship gets there, which means you end up doing a bi-elliptic due to having to wait to sync up with Moho.

11 hours ago, Fwiffo said:

Nevermind, I found some additional metrics in KER that I could add to the target info window, I think it has everything I need.

Does this look correct?  I'm a bit surprised as this thing is telling me it's a lot cheaper (in terms of delta V) to leave from Kerbin than from orbit of Moho or Eve (I wanted to check from Gilly but that moon isn't in his planner):

 

I just plugged the same basic data into AlexMoon's planner and got a very very different result.

It gave me very similar results to my spreadsheet: 2800 m/s ejection burn (which I guess should give a Vinf of around 4000 m/s), and "capture" burn of 6225 m/s.

I uploaded pics but Imgur is spazzing out for me right now...

8 minutes ago, Geschosskopf said:

But because you're leaving when Kerbin is in the right place vs. Moho's orbit, you're paying no attention to where on its orbit Moho is at the time.  Thus, it's not likely that Moho will be at its node when your ship gets there, which means you end up doing a bi-elliptic due to having to wait to sync up with Moho.

Ah, ok. I was thinking you were meaning bi-elliptic as in you burn to one orbit (generally higher, to minimise plane change), travel half an orbit, then burn a second time to get to your real orbit Pe or Ap, then travel another half an orbit, then burn a third time to circularise.

As in, what is visible here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bi-elliptic_transfer

To go to Moho, you don't do two half-ellipses. You do one, then burn to capture a whole orbit later. I wouldn't call that a bi-elliptic transfer.

That means that I think we are describing exactly the same process.

Edited May 16, 2016 by Plusck

7 hours ago, Plusck said:

My spreadsheet (which works fine when I plug the stock planets' parameters in, except for inclination which I haven't added in yet) tells me that to get to this vessel's orbit, you need a Vinf of 4004* m/s leaving Kerbin (compared to a maximum Vinf of 2900 m/s to reach Moho's Pe), and you will need 6230 m/s to match orbits with it.

Leaving from Eve, you'd need a Vinf of 3830m/s and an orbit-matching burn of 5420m/s (on average, again discounting inclination changes).

And leaving from Moho, you'd need a Vinf of somewhere between 1740 m/s (if you leave at Moho's Ap) and 3660m/s (if you leave at Moho's Pe) and orbit-matching burn of between 4000 m/s in the first case and 2300 m/s in the second case.

The real numbers from Moho will be significantly higher since Moho's incination is a killer.

*(edit: checking another formula I had saved somewhere, a Vinf of 4004 on leaving Kerbin's SOI requires a burnout velocity of 5148m/s from an altitude of 75km around Kerbin. Deducting orbital velocity of slightly less than 2300 m/s leaves an ejection burn of about 2850m/s from LKO.) 

Thanks for these numbers.  It sounds like you are saying it basically makes more sense to fly this directly from LKO than to utilize a fueling station in the vicinity of Moho / Eve?

I had intended to put a mining station on Moho or Gilly, and send a giant tank of fuel from one of those to something like the edge of their SOI.  Then refuel my rescue craft ("last stop for gas") before it continues deeper into the Kerbol gravity well.

Also seems I was calculating dV's wrong.  Any chance you could share with me how to calculate approx dV's for arbitrary endpoints in the solar system (generally the endpoints would be fixed orbital altitudes above Kerbol or non-Kerbin planets)?  If you have a spreadsheet to make it easier please share!

Edited May 16, 2016 by Fwiffo

40 minutes ago, Fwiffo said:

 

It sounds like you are saying it makes more sense to fly this directly from LKO than to utilize a fueling station in the vicinity of Moho / Eve?

I had been intending on putting in a mining station on Moho or Gilly, and sending a tank of fuel from one of those to something like the edge of their SOI.  Then refueling my rescue craft ("last stop for gas") before it continues deeper into the Kerbol gravity well.

Well, the numbers are what they are. The lowest total is clearly Moho - but if you start from Moho's Ap you have a lower ejection burn but large orbit-matching burn, and if you start from Moho's Pe it's the other way round.

Still, as I said my spreadsheet doesn't account for inclination (if you want to try it, it's here: gateorbits.xlsx. Just add your vessel's SMA and eccentricity into sixth position, while deleting the other orbital info for that "planet", and you'll get all the Vinf data to/from Kerbin, Moho and Eve on the right hand side...). Moho's inclination is pretty huge, so that far down into the sun's gravity well it may end up costing more than going from Eve.

So total dv cost from Kerbin is about 9km/s. From Moho it is just under 6km/s plus plane change. I'm sorry but I really can't remember what the plane change will cost at Moho. I'll load up a game in a couple of minutes and check. However I doubt it is as much as 3km/s, so Moho would probably be cheapest... just. Eve would certainly be cheaper (but maybe, at the end of the day, slower and more of a pain?).

(edit: just tried this in my main savegame, leaving from Moho and trying to reduce inclination relative to Eve and/or Kerbin.

Unfortunaly the setup wasn't perfect to do this, but in very approximate terms it looks like you'll need about 1700m/s normal/antinormal from Moho to get to your target orbit.

This can be combined with your ejection burn, so it'll cost less than that in total, but for a ballpark figure I'd say you should budget for an additional 1200-1500m/s to correct inclination if you're refuelling at Moho.)

(edit 2 - very important here - my numbers give only Vinf. This is your velocity on leaving the SOI. Unfortunately I haven't yet added the equations needed to convert this into a burnout velocity (Vbo) which is the total velocity you need at a given altitude to obtain that Vinf.

However, if you use my spreadsheet you can get this by cheating a little. In the second spreadsheet, you can add a moon and get the Vbo from that moon. Simply make a pretend moon with very low mass at your starting altitude, and the equations will work themselves out. So to leave from 75km Kerbin orbit, give the moon a mass of 1 and radius of 1 at an orbit radius of 675000 and you'll get (almost) the right Vbo for the transfer you're looking from. Obviously you can do this from Moho too... but again without inclination being taken into account)

(edit 3: yeah, yeah, I know, Vbo isn't useful since what you want is the ejection burn amount. To get that, you need to subtract your orbiting velocity from Vbo... At a 75km circular LKO, that means subtracting 2300 m/s (approx). From Moho, that'll be about 1000 m/s...)

Edited May 16, 2016 by Plusck
